facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 16, 1963 of the Rajasthan High Court in D. B. Election Appeal No. 74 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 16, 1963 of the Rajasthan High Court in D. B. Election Appeal No. 74 of 1963.

facts.text: The appellant, Sheopat Singh, and two others, namely Ramchander Chowdhary and Suria Ram, contested the election for a seat in the Rajasthan Legislative Assembly from Hanumangarh constituency.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, Sheopat Singh, and two others, namely Ramchander Chowdhary and Suria Ram, companytested the election for a seat in the Rajasthan Legislative Assembly from Hanumangarh companystituency.

facts.text: The appellant polled 1,285 votes, Ramchander Chowdhary polled 18,217 votes, Surja Ram polled 1,285 votes.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant polled, 1,285 votes Ramchander Chowdhary, 18,217 and Surja Ram, 1,285 votes.

facts.text: The appellant was declared elected.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was declared elected.

facts.text: The respondent, one of the electors, filed an election petition under S. 81 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, for setting aside the election of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent, One of the electors, filed an election petition under S. 8 1 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951, hereinafter called the Act, for setting aside the election of the appellant on various grounds.

facts.text: Election Tribunal by its order dated June 18, 1963, dismissed the petition.

anchor.surface_text: Me Election Tribunal. by its order dated June 18. 1963, held that the respondent had failed to substantiate the allegations made against the appellant and, on that finding, dismissed the petition.

facts.text: Respondent preferred an appeal to the Rajasthan High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against the said order, the respondent preferred an appeal to the High Court of Judicature for Rajasthan at Jodhpur.

facts.text: Division Bench of Rajasthan High Court held that the appellant was guilty of corrupt practice under sub-s. (4) of s. 123 of the Act in publishing poster Ex. 3.

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of that Court heard the appeal and came to the, companyclusion that the appellant was guilty of a companyrupt practice under sub-s.  4  of s. 123 of the Act in publishing a poster, Ex. 3, which companytained a statement of fact about the personal character and companyduct Of Ramchander Chowdhary

facts.text: High Court set aside the order of the Election Tribunal and declared the election of the appellant void.

anchor.surface_text: On that finding, it set aside the order of the Election Tribunal and declared the election of the appellant void.

facts.text: Appellant preferred appeal to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant, by special leave, has preferred this appeal to this Court against the said order of the High Court.

facts.text: Ex. 3 is a poster published and circulated by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: i  that Ex. 3, the poster, published and circulated by the appellant is number hit by the provisions of S. 123  4  of the Act

facts.text: Poster Ex. 3 contained a statement of fact about the personal character and conduct of Ramchander Chowdhary.

anchor.surface_text: publishing a poster, Ex. 3, which companytained a statement of fact about the personal character and companyduct Of Ramchander Chowdhary, one of the candidates in the election.

facts.text: Ramchander Chowdhary was the Minister-in-charge of the Rajasthan Canal Project.

anchor.surface_text: At the crucial time, Ramchander Chowdhary was the Minister-in-charge of the Rajasthan Canal Project.

facts.text: Adarsh Theatre in Ganganagar belongs to Ramchander Chowdhary and his sons. Admitted by appellant and his agent.

anchor.surface_text: It is admitted by the appellant and his agent that the theatre referred to in the poster is the Adarsh Theatre and it belongs to Ramchander Chowdhary and his sons.

facts.text: The poster Ex. 3 referred to the cinema theatre (Adarsh Theatre) being built by misappropriating cement from Rajasthan Canal.

anchor.surface_text: the first paragraph of the poster means that the cinema theatre of Rs. 7 lakhs in Gangangar was the barkat of the cement of the Rajasthan canal. That means by misappropriating the cement of the Rajasthan Canal the cinema theatre worth Rs. 7 lakhs was built.

facts.text: P.W. 4, Dharam Pal, stated that 4,000 bags of cement were used in construction of the cinema theatre: 2,000 from Sawai Madhopur, 1,585 from Charkhidadri, 415 local.

anchor.surface_text: P.W. 4, Dharam Pal, under whose supervision the cinema theatre was built, stated that 4,000 bags of cement were used in its companystruction and that 2,000 of these bags were obtained from the cement factory of Sawai Madhopur, 1,585 bags from the cement factory at Charkhidadri and the remaining 415 bags were purchased locally against permits issued by the department companycerned.

facts.text: Evidence of P.W. 4 accepted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This evidence has been accepted by the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant and D.W. 7 admitted that Ramchander Chowdhary was an honest man.

anchor.surface_text: not only the appellant did number adduce any evidence to rebut the evidence adduced by the respondent but the appellant as well as his witness, D.W. 7, admitted in the witness-box that Ramchander Chowdhary was an honest man.

facts.text: Hariram, father of the appellant, was a duly nominated candidate who withdrew his candidature before the election.

anchor.surface_text: Hariram, the father of the appellant, was one Of the candidates who stood for the election. His numberination paper was held to be valid. But, later on, he withdrew his candidature.

facts.text: Election petition alleged that appellant got printed posters and leaflets containing imputations against Ramchander Chowdhary, distributed by appellant and Hariram among others.

anchor.surface_text: In the election petition it was stated that the appellant got printed from lqbal Printing Press, Sri Ganganagar, hundreds and thousands of posters and leaflets companytaining grossly libellous and highly defamatory imputations against Ramchander Chowdhary and that the appellant himself and through his workers and supporters got them published... names of the distributor... Sheopat Singh... and his father, Hariram

facts.text: No allegation in election petition that Hariram believed the statement to be false or did not believe it to be true.

anchor.surface_text: But there is numberallegation that Hariram published the statement believing it to be false or number believing it to be true.

facts.text: Supreme Court held that Ex. 3 is hit by s.123(4) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore hold that Ex. 3 is hit by s. 123  4  of the Act and, therefore, the High Court rightly held that the appellant was guilty of companyrupt practice.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court's finding that appellant guilty of corrupt practice.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court rightly held that the appellant was guilty of companyrupt practice.

facts.text: Hariram not joined as respondent in election petition, but no corrupt practice alleged against him, so s.85 not attracted.

anchor.surface_text: In the absence of any such averment, it cannot be held that there was any allegation of any companyrupt practice within the meaning of S. 8 2  b  of the Act against Hariram. In that event, as there was numberallegation of a companyrupt practice against Hariram, the penal provisions of s. 85 are number attracted.

holdings.text: We, therefore, hold that any statement made, which reflects on the mental or moral character of a person is a reflection on his personal character, whereas any criticism of a persons political or public activities and policies is outside it.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore hold that any statement made, which reflects on the mental or moral character of a person is a reflection on his personal character, whereas any criticism of a persons political or -public activities and policies is outside it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Drawing boundary between personal (mental/moral nature, actions reflecting deficiency like bribe-taking) and public/political, following precedents in Gangi Reddy and Inder Lal; applied to misappropriation allegation against minister.

holdings.text: Under s. 123(4) of the Act mens rea is a necessary ingredient of the corrupt practice and the person who publishes a statement, whether he is the author of it or not, does not commit a corrupt practice, unless he has the requisite knowledge. The sub-section does not accept the doctrine of constructive knowledge.

precedents.citation: T. K. Gangi Reddy v. M. C. Anjaneya Reddy

anchor.surface_text: T. K. Gangi Reddy v. M. C. Anjaneya Reddy  . In that case, dealing with the question of burden of proof, this Court observed Burden of proof has two distinct meanings, viz.,  i  the burden of proof as a matter of law and pleading, and  ii  the burden of proof as a matter of adducing evidence The first remain-, companystant and the second shifts.

precedents.case_name: T. K. Gangi Reddy v. M. C. Anjaneya Reddy
precedents.cited_proposition: Burden of proof in election petitions alleging corrupt practices: burden of law and adducing evidence initially on petitioner seeking to set aside election; shifts if sufficient evidence adduced; becomes academic after all evidence recorded
precedents.cited_holding: Burden of proof as a matter of law and as a matter of adducing evidence is on the respondent, who seeks to get the election set aside, to establish corrupt practice but, if he adduces sufficient evidence, as in this case we are satisfied he has, the burden of adducing evidence shifts on to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Gangi Reddys case 1 , dealing with the said expression, this Court observed at p. 266 thus The words personal character or companyduct are so clear that they do number require further elucidation or definition. The character of a person may ordinarily be equated with his mental or moral nature. Conduct companynotes a persons actions or behaviour What is more damaging to a persons character and companyduct than to state that he instigated a murder and that he was guilty of violent acts in his political career in

precedents.case_name: T. K. Gangi Reddy v. M. C. Anjaneya Reddy
precedents.cited_proposition: Meaning of 'personal character or conduct': character equates to mental or moral nature; conduct to actions or behaviour
precedents.cited_holding: The words personal character or companyduct are so clear that they do number require further elucidation or definition. The character of a person may ordinarily be equated with his mental or moral nature. Conduct companynotes a persons actions or behaviour

anchor.surface_text: Inder Lal v. Lal Singh 2 , this Court again, adverting to this aspect, observed thus In discussing the distinction between the private character and the public character, sometimes reference is made to the man beneath the politician and it is said that if a statement of fact affects the man beneath the politician it touches private character and if it affects the politician, it does number touch his private character. After referring to obvious statements which affect the private character of a person, this Court proceeded to state But there may be cases on the border-line where the false statement may affect both the politician and the man beneath the politician and it is precisely in dealing with cases on the border-line that difficulties are experienced in determining whether the impugned false statement companystitutes a companyrupt practice or number.

precedents.cited_proposition: Distinction between private/personal character and public character of a politician; borderline cases where statement affects both
precedents.cited_holding: In discussing the distinction between the private character and the public character, sometimes reference is made to the man beneath the politician... there may be cases on the border-line where the false statement may affect both the politician and the man beneath the politician

precedents.citation: Nevill v. Fine Art and General Insurance Co. Ltd. 1

anchor.surface_text: In Nevill v. Fine Art and General Insurance Co. Ltd. 1  Lord Halsbury, L.C., accepted the principle that the questioned document should be taken in a defamatory sense by those to whom it was published according to the primary meaning of the language used in it. In The Capital and Counties Bank Ltd. v.
